misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay linked after sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array will also keep the corresponding names aligned automatically, so that a[n-1] will still be the name of the student who earned b[n-1] after sorting.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort(b) reorders only the int[] b. The String[] a is unchanged. Parallel arrays require you to swap/move both arrays’ elements together when sorting, or to use a combined structure (e.g., objects) so the name-score relationship is preserved.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints the last-entered name (a[n-1]) paired with the highest score after sorting, which is often a mismatched name/score.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Sorting is required, but not used correctly to find the top student
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after sorting scores, the top student can be retrieved by simply taking the last elements of both arrays, without ensuring the name array was sorted in the same way.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Even though sorting scores makes b[n-1] the maximum, the associated name is not necessarily a[n-1] unless the name array was permuted identically. Alternatively, you can skip sorting and directly track the max score and its index while reading.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output on many inputs (e.g., sample: would output "Charlie (92)" instead of "Bob (92)").

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array (the scores array) while keeping the other array (the names array) unchanged will maintain the correspondence between names and scores. The student thinks that after sorting `b` in ascending order, the element at index `n-1` will still correspond to the same student name at index `n-1` in array `a`.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student lacks understanding of how parallel arrays must be kept synchronized during operations. When `Arrays.sort(b)` is called, it sorts the scores array in-place, but the names array is not affected. This breaks the index-based correspondence between the two arrays. The name at `a[n-1]` no longer corresponds to the highest score in `b[n-1]`. To maintain parallel array integrity, any sorting operation on one array must be mirrored on the other, typically through a custom sorting algorithm or by creating an index mapping.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program will print the last name in the input list paired with the highest score from the sorted scores, rather than the actual highest-scoring student's name. For the sample input, it would print 'Charlie (92)' instead of 'Bob (92)'.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are conceptually 'parallel' (sharing the same index for related data), the Java execution environment will automatically maintain the relationship between elements even if one array is reordered.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The 'parallel' nature of arrays is a programmer's convention, not a feature of the language or the JVM. Calling Arrays.sort() on one array modifies its internal order but has no knowledge of or effect on other arrays, resulting in a loss of data integrity between the names and scores.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Stay Aligned After Sorting One Array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the scores array will also keep the corresponding names in the same relative order, so the highest score at b[n-1] still matches the correct student name at a[n-1].
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(b)` only reorders the elements of the `b` array. It does not (and cannot) automatically reorder a separate parallel array (`a`) to maintain the name↔score pairing. To sort student records by score, you must either: (1) swap elements in both arrays together during sorting, or (2) create a combined structure (e.g., a `Student` class or an array of indices) and sort that.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed name may not belong to the highest score after sorting `b` (name-score association is broken). It only works by coincidence when the top scorer was already last in the original input order.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting one array (scores) will automatically keep the corresponding data in the parallel array (names) synchronized by index. When they access the last element of each array after sorting, they expect both to correspond to the same student.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student doesn't understand that `Arrays.sort()` only modifies the specific array it's called on. When you have parallel arrays, sorting one array breaks the index correspondence between them. After sorting the scores array, the name at index i no longer corresponds to the score at index i. To maintain parallel array integrity during sorting, you must either: (1) swap elements in both arrays together using custom logic, (2) store index-tracking information to map old positions to new positions, or (3) use a data structure that keeps the name and score together (like an object or 2D array).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are intended to be parallel (sharing the same index for related data), sorting one array will automatically reorder the elements in the other array to maintain the semantic relationship between their elements.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects in memory with no intrinsic link. The 'parallel' nature of arrays is a conceptual framework maintained by the programmer through logic, not a feature of the language or the standard library. Calling Arrays.sort() on one array only modifies the memory of that specific array, leading to a loss of the original index-based association between names and scores.
